commander.name: Terry de la Mesa Allen Sr.
commander.previous_service: Commanded 1st Infantry Division from May 1942 through Tunisia and Sicily campaigns. Previously commanded cavalry units. Relieved August 1943 after Sicily.

M2A1 105mm Howitzer.notes: Three light artillery battalions (7th, 32nd, 33rd FA Bn), each with 12 guns

M1 155mm Howitzer.notes: One medium artillery battalion (5th FA Bn)

2.36\" M1 Bazooka.notes: Man-portable rocket launcher, not counted in artillery total

.50 cal M2HB (mounted).notes: Limited organic AA, vehicle-mounted .50 cal MGs

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate by April-June 1943. Improved logistics through Tunisian ports after initial Torch landing difficulties. Supply lines 150-300km from Oran/Algiers. Water critical in North African operations, especially during final Tunisia offensive.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Mixed North African terrain: coastal plains, rocky hills (Djebels), wadis, limited desert sectors

subordinate_units.notes: Three infantry battalions, cannon company, anti-tank company, service company. Fought at El Guettar, Mateur, Bizerte.
Three infantry battalions, cannon company, anti-tank company, service company. Fought at Longstop Hill, El Guettar, Béja.
Three infantry battalions, cannon company, anti-tank company, service company. Raided Maknassy, fought at El Guettar, final Tunis offensive.
105mm M2A1 howitzers (12 guns). Direct support 16th Infantry Regiment.
105mm M2A1 howitzers (12 guns). Direct support 18th Infantry Regiment.
105mm M2A1 howitzers (12 guns). Direct support 26th Infantry Regiment.
155mm M1 howitzers (12 guns). General support, division artillery.
M8 Greyhound armored cars, M20 scout cars, jeeps. Division reconnaissance.
Mine clearing, bridge building, demolitions, road construction. Critical in Tunisia terrain.
Traffic control, POW handling, rear area security

tactical_doctrine.role: Standard infantry division: assault, hold terrain, sustained combat operations. Tunisia Campaign: break Axis defensive lines in mountainous terrain.
special_capabilities: Night operations (18th RCT at Longstop Hill)
Combined arms coordination with attached armor
tactical_innovations: Use of Rangers for special operations (El Guettar)
known_issues: 37mm anti-tank gun obsolete against German armor
Initial lack of combat experience (early Tunisia)
Discipline issues noted by Omar Bradley (later relieved Aug 1943)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Increased water carrying capacity, desert uniforms, sun protection, vehicle sand filters, reduced marching loads

special_rules: Terry Allen aggressive leadership: +1 to assault actions
Regimental Combat Team flexibility: Can detach/attach battalions
Veteran status: Improved rally checks after Tunisia combat
Big Red One esprit de corps: +1 morale in prolonged engagements
historical_engagements: El Guettar (23 March - 7 April 1943) - Major tank battle
Tunisia Campaign end (9 May 1943) - 240,000 Axis POWs

exact_subordinate_strengths.estimate_method: Used standard TO&E authorized strengths from FM 7-20 and Nafziger 943UQ series. Infantry regiments at 3,120 each (1943 TO&E). Artillery battalions 520-580. Support companies 150-220. Howe provides casualty context showing units were at reasonable strength during Tunisia operations.
